head.title: Postings: Panel on Reusing Historic Complexes; Recycling Writ Large

hedline.hl1: Postings: Panel on Reusing Historic Complexes; Recycling Writ Large

abstract.p: Municipal Art Society and Historic Districts Council sponsor panel discussion on reusing historic complexes in New York and other cities (S)

block.p: The Municipal Art Society and the Historic Districts Council will sponsor a free panel discussion on Tuesday about reusing such large historic complexes as Ellis Island, the Farm Colony-Sea View Historic District on Staten Island, Governors Island and the Presidio in San Francisco.

This week's discussion will be the first of three public programs that focus on the Farm Colony-Sea View Historic District in the Greenbelt area of central Staten Island occupied by a rehabilitation center and home and a now-abandoned county poorhouse. Also on view at the society's Madison Avenue offices, through Sept. 16, is an exhibition on the district illustrating its architectural and environmental features and presenting ways to to ensure its future.

The Municipal Art Society and the Historic Districts Council will sponsor a free panel discussion on Tuesday about reusing such large historic complexes as Ellis Island, the Farm Colony-Sea View Historic District on Staten Island, Governors Island and the Presidio in San Francisco.

This week's discussion will be the first of three public programs that focus on the Farm Colony-Sea View Historic District in the Greenbelt area of central Staten Island occupied by a rehabilitation center and home and a now-abandoned county poorhouse. Also on view at the society's Madison Avenue offices, through Sept. 16, is an exhibition on the district illustrating its architectural and environmental features and presenting ways to to ensure its future.

Panelists for Tuesday's event, to be held at the Municipal Art Society Urban Center, 457 Madison Avenue ( 51st Street), will be Peg Breen, the president of the New York Landmarks Conservancy; Gloria Root, a former chairwoman of the Presidio task force; and Michael A. Tomlan, director of Cornell's graduate program of historic preservation planning.

The panel discussion, from 6 p.m. until 7:30 p.m., will be moderated by Brendan Sexton, the president of the Times Square Business Improvement District and a co-chairman of the Municipal Art Society Planning Committee.
